articles.headline: Consumers Came Back in June, but for How Long?
articles.snippet: Retail sales increased 7.5 percent, but there are ominous signs that the rebound may fizzle as coronavirus cases rise through much of the country.
articles.abstract: Retail sales increased 7.5 percent, but there are ominous signs that the rebound may fizzle as coronavirus cases rise through much of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American consumer came back last month, with retail sales increasing 7.5 percent from May as stores reopened in warm weather, shoppers shook off lockdown fatigue and the federal government pumped trillions of dollars of stimulus into the economy.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari, Michael Corkery and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Under Hedge Fund Set to Own McClatchy, Canadian Newspapers Endured Big Cuts
articles.snippet: Since Chatham Asset Management took over Postmedia, Canada’s largest newspaper chain, 1,600 employees have been laid off and more than 30 papers shut down.
articles.abstract: Since Chatham Asset Management took over Postmedia, Canada’s largest newspaper chain, 1,600 employees have been laid off and more than 30 papers shut down.
articles.lead_paragraph: In October 2016, a New Jersey hedge fund assumed ownership of Canada’s largest newspaper chain with very little fanfare. Few people noticed, including some of the chain’s employees.

articles.headline: What the Twitter Hack Revealed: An Election System Teeming With Risks
articles.snippet: The breach that targeted Joe Biden, Barack Obama and others served as a warning: Had it happened on Nov. 3, hoping to upend the election, the political fallout could have been quite different.
articles.abstract: The breach that targeted Joe Biden, Barack Obama and others served as a warning: Had it happened on Nov. 3, hoping to upend the election, the political fallout could have been quite different.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past year government officials have raced to help states replace voting machines that leave no paper trail, and to harden vulnerable online voter registration systems that many fear Russia, or others, could hijack to trigger chaos on Election Day.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Mask Rules Expand Across U.S. as Clashes Over the Mandates Intensify
articles.snippet: More retailers and states are instituting mask requirements, but tensions are mounting for people who see the rules as infringements.
articles.abstract: More retailers and states are instituting mask requirements, but tensions are mounting for people who see the rules as infringements.
articles.lead_paragraph: As images of people wearing surgical masks flashed across the screen, Morgan Freeman’s deep, soothing voice delivered a message to America: “When you wear a mask, you have my respect. Because your mask doesn’t protect you — it protects me.”
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Manny Fernandez and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: China’s Swimwear Capital Can’t Wait for You to Go Back to the Beach
articles.snippet: When the pandemic shut down pools and resorts around the globe, life slid to a halt in the seaside town of Xingcheng, a major producer of bikinis and trunks.
articles.abstract: When the pandemic shut down pools and resorts around the globe, life slid to a halt in the seaside town of Xingcheng, a major producer of bikinis and trunks.
articles.lead_paragraph: There may be no place on earth that had been looking forward to summer more than Xingcheng, a laid-back seaside town dotted with the occasional high rise.

articles.headline: The Democrats Are Downsizing Their Convention to Almost Nothing
articles.snippet: An event that was once expected to draw 50,000 people to Milwaukee may now involve just 300, with plans still far from settled a month before the convention.
articles.abstract: An event that was once expected to draw 50,000 people to Milwaukee may now involve just 300, with plans still far from settled a month before the convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Democrats awarded their 2020 convention to Milwaukee, plans called for a crowd of more than 50,000 delegates, journalists, party officials and V.I.P.s. But as the coronavirus spread this spring and the convention was pushed back to August, the number dwindled.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: For Owners of Century-Old Businesses, Shutting Down Brings a Special Pain
articles.snippet: A department store, a barbecue restaurant, a hotel — all had survived some of the biggest trials in history. Their owners are mourning the loss of a legacy.
articles.abstract: A department store, a barbecue restaurant, a hotel — all had survived some of the biggest trials in history. Their owners are mourning the loss of a legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harrell’s Department Store has stood sentry over Wright Street in Burgaw, N.C., for the past 117 years. It has served the town’s 4,000 residents with everything they’ve needed, like baby shoes and horse collars in the original wooden building, or church hats and appliances in the two-story red brick building constructed in 1924.

articles.headline: Airbnb Was Like a Family, Until the Layoffs Started
articles.snippet: What happens when a kumbaya office culture meets the business realities of a pandemic?
articles.abstract: What happens when a kumbaya office culture meets the business realities of a pandemic?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On May 5, after almost two months of working alone in his San Francisco apartment, Brian Chesky, Airbnb’s chief executive, cried into his video camera.

articles.headline: Federal Agents Unleash Militarized Crackdown on Portland
articles.snippet: Federal authorities said they would bring order to Portland, Ore., after weeks of protests there. Local leaders believe the federal presence is making things worse.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities said they would bring order to Portland, Ore., after weeks of protests there. Local leaders believe the federal presence is making things worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Federal agents dressed in camouflage and tactical gear have taken to the streets of Portland, unleashing tear gas, bloodying protesters and pulling some people into unmarked vans in what Gov. Kate Brown of Oregon has called “a blatant abuse of power.”
articles.byline: By Sergio Olmos, Mike Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: How to Save a Half-Open Economy
articles.snippet: It may take months or even years to recover its vigor. Here’s how economists say the government could help.
articles.abstract: It may take months or even years to recover its vigor. Here’s how economists say the government could help.
articles.lead_paragraph: When states began to order businesses to close and residents to stay home as the coronavirus outbreak spread, economists likened the policy to a medically induced coma: shutting down all but the most vital functions to focus on the underlying affliction.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Federal Aid Has So Far Averted Personal Bankruptcies, but Trouble Looms
articles.snippet: Once federal benefits dry up, highly indebted consumers could be forced to file.
articles.abstract: Once federal benefits dry up, highly indebted consumers could be forced to file.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States went into the Great Lockdown with the most household debt in history, stagnant incomes for all but high earners and armies of people telling pollsters they were living paycheck to paycheck. Then, for millions, their paychecks stopped.
